lines.text: I'd like to welcome you to the studio.
Wow! This is really fantastic! It looks just like the real thing!
That's why we wanted you here to advise us, make sure we're doing it right. After-all, this is your life story.
No problem. As long as you got the right people to play us. Admit it, Redford was dying to play me, right?
Not exactly. Here's the cast list.
Murray, Aykroyd and Ramis? What's that - a law firm?
It's times like this that I wish I'd listened to what my dad used to tell me.
Yeah? What was that?
I don't know. I never listened.

[during a dream]
A good imagination is a joy forever.
Notice the vacant stare, the completely mindless look. That could only mean one thing.
She's from California?
No. She's been hypnotized.
Oh, Peter. Will you tell me a bedtime story?
Okay. Once upon a time there were four Ghostbusters who were trying to catch the Boogeyman but they couldn't because one of them wouldn't shut up and go to sleep. The end.
Sometimes I think the universe just waits for me to get cocky.
You know, we're all descendants from fish. It would be no trouble at all to flip back in time, find the fish you descended from, and stuff it into a Cuisinart.
This is almost as much fun as catching bowling balls with my teeth.
Peter, do you know how to set your proton pack on explosive overload?
No.
I do.
This is not fun! I've had fun! This isn't it!

[plugging in a wire]
Let's see. I can never remember if it's positive to negative or positive to positive.
[the Ghostbusters respond to a false alarm]
We should have charged her for the call.
Come on, Peter. She was someone's grandmother.
As long as she wasn't mine.

[Falsetto voice]
I think I shall never see a poem as lovely as a tree.
Ray's fine now.
[Egon takes Peter to the opera]
The Met? I thought you said the Mets.
Anybody having any luck?
That depends. You mean, like, good luck?
Would you be Mr. Raymond Stantz?
No, not by choice.
[Peter and Egon are going to search for a troll in the Holland Tunnel]

[shouting]
Remember there could be giant ants, like in Santa Clara, in 1950!
[Egon backs the car up and Peter rolls down the window]
Not funny.
He did it again! He slimed me in my sleep.
[Ray, Egon and Winston try holding Peter back]
Just let me zap him with the proton blaster. Please.
Woah, Peter. Just calm down and ask him why he was sleeping in your bed.
Okay, we'll try it your way. Slimer, come here. Why were you sleeping in my bed?
[Slimer quickly begins to explain to Peter that his night light burnt out and he didn't want to sleep by himself]
You mean to tell me that you couldn't sleep in your own bed because your night light burnt out and you didn't want to sleep by yourself? That's great.
Hey, I've got an idea... HEY, SLIMER! PIZZA!
Is it over?
No, I think I'm still alive.

[Peter singing in the shower when suddenly Slimer pours out of the faucet above and onto his head]
Slimer! How about some privacy!
If I ever see another bug again it'll be too soon. Like I said before, the world would be better off without them.
That's not true, Peter. The world couldn't survive without insects.
That's right. Our whole eco-system depends on them. So give them a break, all right?
But they're all so ugly!
Look again, Peter!
[a brightly colored butterfly lands on Peter's nose]
You know, I think this could be the start of a beautiful friendship.
Beautiful!

[Ray has just plowed through a pretzel stand to avoid an oncoming vehicle]
That road hog!

[holding a bag of pretzels]
Nice driving, Ray!
[then to a stunned Winston]
Pretzel?
[after a magic book zooms down a pit, as part of Vladimir's ceremony to summon an "Old One"]
Flee, before I destroy you all!
Excuse me, but did it occur to you that your best weapon against us was that book, and that now it's down there, and you, you're pretty much up here?
...Good point.

[translating the grumblings of Venkman, who just woke up]
Get out of my face or eat flaming terror.
